Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Rapid host-parasite evolution and its effects on host invasions: a resurrection ecology study
Award.AbstractNarration:
As rates of parasitism increase and species invasions skyrocket, there are increasing numbers of outbreaks of disease that result from novel host-parasite pairings. How do hosts and parasites evolve in response to these new interactions, and what are the consequences for ecological dynamics of native and invasive hosts? This project uses interactions among a native bacterial parasite, a native zooplankton host, and an invasive zooplankton host that is now infected by the native bacterial parasite to ask how parasites adapt when they first enter a novel host. Existing genetic archives for both host and parasite provide a rare opportunity to study the important process of how pathogens that originate in one host species move to another; this host switch is very difficult to observe in nature. In addition, observational studies of lake populations, laboratory experiments and mathematical models will be used to understand how parasitism influences population dynamics of native and invasive hosts.

An important component of this project involves educating, training and diversifying the next generation of scientists. The principal investigator will work with science educators to develop hands-on, experiential learning activities for inner city children in Atlanta, focusing on plankton and microbes. Informal science education activities aimed at the general public will also be developed, and will be used to engage visitors to an inner city park. Pre-teacher undergraduates from Georgia Tech will be trained in scientific research, educational research, and pedagogy. In addition, students from Georgia Tech and nearby Spelman College will be involved in the proposed research, gaining valuable research experience. Finally, because many new human pathogens likely arose in different hosts, understanding the process by which pathogens jump from one host to another will have broad societal significance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As rates of parasitism and species invasions increase worldwide, there are increasing numbers of disease outbreaks that result from novel host-parasite pairings. What determines whether parasites can move to novel hosts, including invasive species? We worked on two common pathogens (one bacterial and one fungal) that infect many daphniid species, including the invasive host Daphnia lumholtzi. We found that, while these pathogens can move between host species, there is also strong genetic structuring, with pathogen strains isolated from one host species usually (but not always) being distinct from those isolated from a different species. Transmission between host species is more likely if those host species are more closely related. Finally, we found that, while transmission can occur between species, the pathogen has lower fitness when it’s in the “wrong” host species.

When a novel host invades a community and becomes infected by a native pathogen, can we predict what impacts it will have on patterns of disease? We expected that we should be able to use host competence to predict how an invasive species would influence community disease dynamics; specifically, we predicted that the addition of a highly competent invasive host species should increase disease. Surprisingly, we found that the addition of a highly competent invasive host species actually decreased disease in the native host. This occurred because the invasive host was a strong resource competitor, decreasing host density, which decreased disease. Thus, information on host competence alone may not accurately predict how an invasive species will influence disease in native species.  

During the work on this project, we sometimes found hosts who were coinfected – that is, cases where a single host individual had two parasite species inside it. We tested how coinfection influenced host and pathogen fitness. We found that the order in which pathogens arrive in a host determined pathogen fitness and ultimately scaled up to alter pathogen coexistence patterns at the community level. Somewhat surprisingly, we found that arriving second increased fitness of the fungal pathogen. Using a mathematical model that we parameterized with our lab experiments, we found that this benefit of second arrival increased the likelihood that the two pathogens would coexist.

This project also supported work with students from underrepresented groups. As part of this work, we led hands on activities that taught school children about lakes, parasites, and ecology. This included leading hands on activities with campers at Piedmont Park in midtown Atlanta in multiple summers, as well as activities with the FEMMES group at the University of Michigan in multiple years; FEMMES aims to get girls in grades 4-6 (particularly those from underrepresented groups) excited about science. This grant supported the training of 22 undergraduates, six of whom are from groups traditionally underrepresented in the sciences. In addition, six of these undergraduate students are coauthors on scientific publications, and four students completed undergraduate honors theses on this project. The project also trained 3 graduate students, 4 postdoctoral researchers, and 4 technicians.

Ten publications from this work have already appeared in print, with an additional publication under review. Several other publications are currently in preparation for submission, and more are likely to be prepared in the future.
